intro: Astragalus neoverticillatus, commonly known as the western bottlebrush milkvetch, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It belongs to the legume family, Fabaceae, and is characterized by its unique, spiny stems and clusters of small, pink to purple flowers. The plant produces pod-like fruits that contain several seeds, typical of the Fabaceae family. It thrives in dry, sandy soils and is often found in grasslands and shrubsteppe habitats. Astragalus neoverticillatus plays a role in stabilizing soil and providing nectar for pollinators.
